Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Evaluating Risk and Uncertainty in Radiation Exposure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How are risk and uncertainly managed amidst low-level radiation exposure? One approach to answering such a question effectively has been to focus on the clearest points of vulnerability. In areas of radiation exposure, children are biologically identified as the most vulnerable population by long-term exposure because of their faster cell division. This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of rigorous scientific data collection and analysis, explores the strategies undertaken by families in evaluating risk and mitigating uncertainty as they raise children in these contexts. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in scientific methods of rigorous data collection and analysis, the project would engage a wider audience in the scientific process, and broadly disseminate its findings to organizations invested in understanding environmental risk.

Duke University anthropology doctoral candidate, Jieun Cho, under the supervision of Dr. Anne Allison will explore the child-rearing and other social practices of parents raising children in areas afflicted by low levels of radiation. In post-meltdown Japan, the effort at constructing normal life continues to raise questions about how, and in what terms, this may be possible when the effects of radioactivity from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster remain uncertain. Despite concerns for health amidst an administratively raised level of permissible airborne radiation (which is necessary for re-building the region), many families have remained in, or returned to, their less-than-ideal neighborhoods in Fukushima Prefecture for various reasons like the presence of jobs, aging parents, and family farms. The research on such families in this area and their efforts at maintaining (or restoring) children's health will provide a microcosm for examining the dynamics through which futures are being made in a context with increasing environmental uncertainty. The researcher has chosen to focus on those families in cities across Fukushima Prefecture, where the populations were not evacuated and have chosen to remain, or return, to make lives within a raised level of airborne radiation with little official assistance. Although children's health has become a problem for parents, post-nuclear politics, and future imaginaries in post-Fukushima Japan, research on child-raising practices by ordinary families who are actually striving to survive in this area is almost totally lacking. In employing a combination of participant observation, semi-structured interviews, and document analysis, the researcher will collect sets of data on the strategies of living with radiation adopted by parents who knowingly bring up children in irradiated neighborhoods in Fukushima, the public debates surrounding radioactive uncertainty with regard to victimhood and entitlement in post-nuclear care, and forms of sociality that take shape through anxious care-giving in the post-disaster support networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support from the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant, the Co-PI, Jieun Cho, completed field research for her doctoral dissertation under the working title, "Evaluating Risk and Uncertainty in Radiation Exposure." This fieldwork investigates what conceptions of "life" are re/produced in a risky environment after the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster in Japan. In particular, the project focuses on families who have been raising children in inner cities of Fukushima Prefecture amidst radiation risks while trying to come up with manageable measures of health and well-being. By tracking public and private forms of care for "Fukushima children" in both Tokyo and Fukushima, the research examines ethical/political implications of post-Fukushima radiation risks, considering (1) how do the stakes of low-dose radiation risks get articulated in terms of national history, radiation science, citizen rights, and biological health, and (2) how are the families' stakes for raising healthy children amidst the risky environment formed and managed in the family form and beyond?

During the project period, in order to answer research questions on children's health, family, and post-Fukushima radiation, the Co-PI worked as an unpaid staff at three activist organizations which, respectively: 1) deploy judicial activism to contest the zoning regulations issued by the government for what areas should be officially evacuated (and which not), 2) organize science-inspired charity to support families with children who have developed thyroid cancers after the disaster, and 3) publicize scientific knowledge regarding issues pertaining to radiation risks. These institutions deliver a humanitarian form of care premised on the event of "nuclear problems." The researcher also participated in something rather different: communal forms of care that are premised on the everyday rhythm of families by helping, for example, to organize "health-restoration retreats" for parents and children living amidst radiation risks. Through the connections she developed with child-raising families in Fukushima City, Kōriyama City, Shirakawa City, and Iwaki City of Fukushima Prefecture--major residential cities all of which have been on the frontline of radiation debates for having been exposed to disaster-induced radiation while not designated for evacuation--the Co-PI made home visits, and conducted in-depth interviews to gain insights into how radiation risks to children's health are understood and managed in domestic households and local networks for mutual help.

The time the Co-PI spent conducting ethnographic research with families living amidst low-dose radiation risks in post-nuclear Fukushima helped her understand the ways in which long-term radiation risks continue to affect everyday life for both parents and children in inner cities of Fukushima Prefecture. Major findings include: 1) The "choice" to live knowingly amidst radiation risks was informed by concerns over social discrimination against exposed populations outside Fukushima as much as the widely discussed lack of mobility for financial reasons. In the interviews, concerns over discrimination were largely associated with the historical marginalization of hibakusha (nuclear victims) and their families. 2) Disparate from the radiation risks that are produced for policy based on measurements at fixed locations, the irradiatedness of living environments registers for the residents as a dynamic process between shifting physical conditions and bodily movements. Radiation risks in living environments were generally described in such terms as patchy, sticky, and dense, rather than a coherent value. The qualitative gap in the perception directly affects a local sense of safety. Both parents and children after the disaster have gone through a process of reconfiguring their perception towards living environments. 3) Radiation risks are distributed differentially through gendered norms of social practices such as domestic labor, childcare, and community maintenance work. Despite their significance for a lived sense of safety and well-being, such work are generally dismissed in risk discourses.

Despite the striking visibility of "Fukushima children" as the signature victim of the disaster in risk politics, research on actual families who are raising children amidst post-Fukushima radiation risks is almost totally lacking. By focusing on forms of care and sociality surrounding low-dose radiation, this research contributes to examining altered forms of "life" as conditioned by long-term radiation risks, the role of existing public/private organizations such as the family form in unequal distribution of risks, and the everyday impact of the Fukushima nuclear disaster in terms beyond the exceptional/eventful crisis. The Co-PI is currently analyzing the data collected during fieldwork and writing up her findings in her doctoral dissertation under the supervision of the PI, Dr. Anne Allison.
